metadata.titleEn: Biome reconstruction on the Tibetan Plateau since the Last Glacial Maximum using a machine learning method
metadata.description: This dataset is the biome change data of the Tibetan Plateau since the last glacial maximum which was reconstructed by using a new method. Firstly, a random forest algorithm was applied to establish a pollen-biome classification model for reconstructing past vegetation changes of the Tibetan Plateau, and 1802 modern pollen assemblages from 17 vegetation zones in and around the Tibetan Plateau were used as the training set for the model development.  The random forest model showed a reliable performance (accuracy > 76%) in predicting modern biomes from modern pollen assemblages based on a comparison with the observed biomes. Moreover, the random forest model had a significantly higher accuracy than the traditional biomization method. Then, the newly established random forest model is applied to the paleovegetation reconstruction of 51 fossil pollen sequences of the Tibetan Plateau. New age-depth models were developed for these fossil pollen records using the Bayesian method, and all fossil pollen records were linearly interpolated to 500-year time slices. Finally, the spatiotemporal changes of biomes on the Tibetan plateau over the past 22,000 years at an interval of 500 years were reconstructed by using the random forest model. This dataset can provide evidence for understanding the past variation of alpine vegetation and its mechanism; provide the basis for studying the impact of past climate change on vegetation on the Tibetan Plateau; and provide boundary conditions for climate simulation.
metadata.instructions: The data is stored in Excel format, which contains the geographic information of the fossil sites and the reconstructed vegetation data of them over the past 22,000 years at 500-year intervals.

background: Historical biome changes on the Tibetan Plateau provide important information that improves our understanding of the alpine vegetation responses to climate changes. However, a comprehensively quantitative reconstruction of the historical Tibetan Plateau biomes is not possible due to the lack of quantitative methods that enable appropriate classification of alpine biomes based on proxy data such as fossil pollen records.
research objective: In this study, a pollen-based biome classification model was developed by applying a random forest algorithm (a supervised machine learning method) based on modern pollen assemblages on and around the Tibetan Plateau, and its robustness was assessed by comparing its results with the predictions of the biomisation.
challenges: The unsatisfactory performance of the biomisation method may partly be attributed to the insufficient compatibility between biome classification scheme and vegetation zonation on the Tibetan Plateau.
methods: The modern pollen dataset used as the training set for developing the pollen-biome classification model contained 1802 samples in 17 vegetation zones obtained from locations on and surrounding the Tibetan Plateau. A total of 51 fossil pollen records from the Tibetan Plateau were used to reconstruct past biome changes from the LGM to the present. Modern pollen assemblages and their vegetation type information were used to train the pollen-biome classification model via the random forest algorithm. The model training was performed following the procedures of Sobol and Finkelstein (2018) and Sobol et al. (2019). The random forest model was applied to the fossil pollen data from the Tibetan Plateau to reconstruct the biome changes for each fossil site.
dataset: The modern pollen dataset used as the training set for developing the pollen-biome classification model contained 1802 samples in 17 vegetation zones obtained from locations on and surrounding the Tibetan Plateau. The modern pollen assemblages in the dataset were from surface soils (832 samples), moss polsters (619 samples), and surface lake sediments (351 samples). A total of 51 fossil pollen records from the Tibetan Plateau were used to reconstruct past biome changes from the LGM to the present, which were primarily obtained from the Late Quaternary pollen dataset of eastern continental Asia.
findings: The random forest model had a significantly higher accuracy than the biomisation method, indicating the former is a more suitable tool for reconstructing alpine biome changes on the Tibetan Plateau. The reconstructed biome distribution changes on the Tibetan Plateau generally corresponded to global climate changes and Asian monsoon variations.

Verification.Question: Does the pollen-biome classification model use modern pollen assemblages as a training dataset?

Disjunctive.Question: When developing models to reconstruct historical vegetation changes, is it more effective to apply machine learning methods like random forests or traditional methods like biomisation?
Disjunctive.Answer: machine learning methods like random forests

Disjunctive.Question: Is the primary source of modern pollen data for training datasets derived from surface soils, moss polsters, or surface lake sediments?

Concept Completion.Question: What data collection methods are used to gather modern pollen samples for biome classification on the Tibetan Plateau?
Concept Completion.Answer: surface soils, moss polsters, surface lake sediments

Concept Completion.Question: Where are the fossil pollen records obtained from for reconstructing past biome changes on the Tibetan Plateau?
Concept Completion.Answer: Late Quaternary pollen dataset of eastern continental Asia

Concept Completion.Question: What challenges are faced when using traditional biome classification methods on the Tibetan Plateau?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to gather pollen samples for reconstructing vegetation changes on the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: A data collection method involved gathering modern pollen assemblages from surface soils, moss polsters, and surface lake sediments, totaling 1802 samples in 17 vegetation zones on and surrounding the Tibetan Plateau.

Example.Question: Please provide an example of a challenge encountered when using traditional methods for classifying biomes on the Tibetan Plateau.
Example.Answer: A challenge with traditional methods like biomisation is their unsatisfactory performance, which may partly be due to insufficient compatibility between the biome classification scheme and the vegetation zonation on the Tibetan Plateau.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of a dataset that was used to develop a machine learning model for reconstructing past vegetation changes on the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset is the modern pollen dataset used as the training set for a random forest algorithm-based biome classification model, containing 1802 samples from 17 vegetation zones.

Feature Specification.Question: What characteristics define a dataset used for training a pollen-biome classification model in the context of the Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: modern pollen assemblages, surface soils, moss polsters, surface lake sediments, 1802 samples, 17 vegetation zones

Quantification.Question: How many modern pollen samples are used in a dataset for training a pollen-biome classification model?
What is the number of fossil pollen records used to reconstruct past biome changes on the Tibetan Plateau?
How many vegetation zones are represented in the modern pollen dataset used for training a biome classification model?

Definition.Question: What does 'random forest algorithm' mean in the context of reconstructing historical biome changes using pollen data?
Definition.Answer: In the context of reconstructing historical biome changes using pollen data, the 'random forest algorithm' is a supervised machine learning method applied to modern pollen assemblages on and around the Tibetan Plateau to develop a pollen-based biome classification model. This model is used to predict past biome changes by analyzing fossil pollen records.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'modern pollen dataset' in the context of training a pollen-biome classification model?
Definition.Answer: In this context, a 'modern pollen dataset' refers to a collection of 1802 pollen samples from 17 vegetation zones on and around the Tibetan Plateau, which include samples from surface soils, moss polsters, and surface lake sediments. This dataset is used to train the pollen-biome classification model using the random forest algorithm.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data sources between the modern pollen dataset used for training the random forest model and the fossil pollen records utilized for past biome reconstruction?
Comparison.Answer: The modern pollen dataset consisted of 1802 samples from 17 vegetation zones, sourced from surface soils, moss polsters, and surface lake sediments. In contrast, the fossil pollen records used for past biome reconstruction comprised 51 records primarily obtained from the Late Quaternary pollen dataset of eastern continental Asia.

Interpretation.Question: How might the variety in data sources, such as surface soils, moss polsters, and lake sediments, contribute to the robustness and reliability of the biome reconstruction model?
Interpretation.Answer: The inclusion of modern pollen assemblages from diverse sources like surface soils, moss polsters, and lake sediments enhances the robustness of the biome classification model by providing a comprehensive representation of current vegetation conditions, which is crucial for accurate paleoecological reconstructions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the need for a new method in reconstructing historical Tibetan Plateau biomes based on pollen records?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need arises due to the lack of quantitative methods that enable appropriate classification of alpine biomes based on proxy data such as fossil pollen records. The unsatisfactory performance of traditional methods like biomisation, which may be partly attributed to the insufficient compatibility between biome classification schemes and vegetation zonation on the Tibetan Plateau, also contributes to this need.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it important to use a random forest algorithm for developing a pollen-based biome classification model on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The random forest algorithm is important for developing the model because it provides significantly higher accuracy than traditional methods like biomisation. This increased accuracy makes it a more suitable tool for reconstructing alpine biome changes on the Tibetan Plateau, as it better aligns with the modern pollen assemblages and their corresponding vegetation types.

Causal Consequence.Question: What is the impact of using a random forest algorithm on the accuracy of historical biome reconstruction on the Tibetan Plateau compared to traditional methods?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The random forest model had a significantly higher accuracy than the biomisation method, indicating it is a more suitable tool for reconstructing alpine biome changes on the Tibetan Plateau.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary goal of employing a random forest algorithm for reconstructing past biome changes on the Tibetan Plateau using pollen data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goal of employing a random forest algorithm is to develop a pollen-based biome classification model that is more accurate and suitable for reconstructing alpine biome changes on the Tibetan Plateau, as compared to traditional methods. This approach aims to provide a comprehensive quantitative reconstruction of historical biome changes using modern pollen assemblages as training data.

Goal Orientation.Question: What objectives are targeted by collecting modern pollen data from various sources like surface soils, moss polsters, and lake sediments for biome classification?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective of collecting modern pollen data from diverse sources is to create a comprehensive training dataset that captures a wide range of vegetation zones and conditions on and around the Tibetan Plateau. This diverse dataset is used to train the random forest model, enhancing its ability to accurately classify biomes based on fossil pollen records and reconstruct past vegetation changes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What specific procedures are utilized to collect and prepare modern pollen assemblages for training a machine learning model to reconstruct historical vegetation changes on the Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Modern pollen assemblages are collected from surface soils, moss polsters, and surface lake sediments. The dataset comprises 1802 samples from 17 vegetation zones around the Tibetan Plateau. This dataset is used to train a pollen-biome classification model via a random forest algorithm to enhance the reconstruction of historical vegetation changes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can machine learning techniques, such as the random forest algorithm, be applied to fossil pollen data to accurately reconstruct past biome changes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The random forest algorithm is applied to fossil pollen data from the Tibetan Plateau to develop a pollen-based biome classification model. The model is trained using modern pollen assemblages and their vegetation type information. The random forest model is then used to reconstruct biome changes for each fossil site, demonstrating higher accuracy compared to traditional biomisation methods.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological steps are involved in creating a depth-age model for pollen fossil sequences and how is this integrated with machine learning to assess vegetation changes over time?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A depth-age model for pollen fossil sequences is created using Bayesian methods. Linear interpolation is then used to obtain pollen fossil data at 500-year intervals. These data are input into the random forest model to reconstruct vegetation changes on the Tibetan Plateau over the past 22,000 years, providing insights into the spatial and temporal patterns of these changes.

Enablement.Question: What machine learning techniques enable the accurate reconstruction of historical Tibetan Plateau vegetation changes from pollen data?
Enablement.Answer: The random forest algorithm, a supervised machine learning method, enables the accurate reconstruction of historical Tibetan Plateau vegetation changes from pollen data. This model was developed using modern pollen assemblages as the training set.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of modern pollen data from various sources enhance the development of a biome classification model for the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of modern pollen data from surface soils, moss polsters, and surface lake sediments enhances the development of a biome classification model by providing a comprehensive dataset of 1802 samples from 17 vegetation zones, which improves the model's robustness and accuracy.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable the reconstruction of past biome changes on the Tibetan Plateau using fossil pollen records?
Enablement.Answer: The reconstruction of past biome changes on the Tibetan Plateau is enabled by using a random forest model applied to 51 fossil pollen records, alongside a Bayesian method to establish depth-age models, and linear interpolation to obtain fossil pollen data at 500-year intervals.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset of modern pollen assemblages from the Tibetan Plateau and its surroundings be expected to improve the accuracy of biome classification models?
Expectation.Answer: The use of a dataset containing 1802 samples from 17 vegetation zones provides a comprehensive training set for the random forest model, enhancing its ability to accurately classify alpine biomes based on modern pollen data. This extensive dataset allows for better model training and validation, leading to higher accuracy in the predictions compared to traditional methods.

Expectation.Question: What expectations could researchers have regarding the use of the random forest algorithm compared to traditional biomisation methods for reconstructing historical biomes?
Expectation.Answer: Researchers might expect the random forest algorithm to outperform traditional biomisation methods due to its ability to handle complex, non-linear relationships between the input data and classification outcomes. The model's robustness and higher accuracy in predicting modern vegetation types suggest it could offer more reliable reconstructions of past biome changes on the Tibetan Plateau.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using the random forest algorithm for reconstructing historical biome changes on the Tibetan Plateau compared to traditional methods?
Judgmental.Answer: The random forest algorithm is deemed more effective in this context, as it provides a significantly higher accuracy than the traditional biomisation method. This suggests that the random forest model is a more suitable tool for reconstructing alpine biome changes on the Tibetan Plateau.

Judgmental.Question: What are some potential challenges in collecting pollen data from the Tibetan Plateau, and how might these affect the reliability of the biome reconstruction?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges in collecting pollen data include the compatibility between biome classification schemes and vegetation zonation on the Tibetan Plateau. Such challenges can affect the reliability of biome reconstruction by potentially leading to discrepancies between observed and predicted vegetation types.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify the data collection methods used to gather modern pollen samples for training machine learning models in the context of reconstructing vegetation changes on the Tibetan Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: The modern pollen dataset used as the training set was collected from surface soils (832 samples), moss polsters (619 samples), and surface lake sediments (351 samples) in 17 vegetation zones on and surrounding the Tibetan Plateau.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges faced in using traditional methods for biome classification compared to machine learning approaches on the Tibetan Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: The unsatisfactory performance of the biomisation method may partly be attributed to the insufficient compatibility between the biome classification scheme and vegetation zonation on the Tibetan Plateau. The random forest model demonstrated significantly higher accuracy, indicating it is more suitable for reconstructing alpine biome changes in this region.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the process of reconstructing past vegetation changes using fossil pollen records and machine learning techniques from the Last Glacial Maximum to the present.
Request/Directive.Answer: The process involved using 51 fossil pollen records from the Tibetan Plateau to reconstruct past biome changes. The random forest algorithm was applied to these fossil pollen data, and a Bayesian method was used to re-establish depth-age models for the fossil sequences. Linear interpolation provided fossil pollen data at 500-year intervals to facilitate the reconstruction of vegetation changes over the past 22,000 years.
